Forza Horizon 4 is a true celebration of speed and freedom. The game impresses with its scale and attention to detail: the vast open world of Great Britain, changing seasons, dynamic weather, and stunning graphics create the feeling of a living, breathing world.

Gameplay
A huge selection of cars ‚Äì from classics to supercars.
Each car feels unique, and the controls are intuitive and responsive.
Competitions are varied: on-road racing, off-road racing, drifting, challenges, and even creative missions.

Open World
Great Britain looks incredibly beautiful: picturesque villages, mountain roads, fields, and cities.
The changing seasons completely change the atmosphere and driving style ‚Äì slippery in winter, vibrant and dynamic in summer.
Atmosphere

The soundtrack perfectly underscores the excitement and spirit of the races.
The online mode allows you to compete and interact with other players, creating the feeling of a true car festival.

Conclusion: Forza Horizon 4 is a game you'll want to return to again and again. It offers freedom, excitement, and a true sense of celebration for car lovers. If you're looking for the perfect open-world arcade racing game, this is it.

Man, I hate Xbox games. Old Xbox games weren't this annoying. They started doing it somewhere since mid 2010s, implemented Xbox login requirement (it already was annoying in AoE3:DE), but to make you login every single time you open the game is just evil.

Also, cars slide too much, like you slightly press right/left, and your car loses control on the turn like it is Toyota Supra going full speed, but no, it is just a family car that goe to 100 in 6 seconds, so how does such slow car loses control on a simple turn? Realism? No. Gran Turismo is considered the most realistic game (there is even a documentary about it), even it didn't have such ridiculous controls. That is because you have 10-20 bar options where you slide them left or right to customize your cars "control" or "feel", if you will. But there is no simple guide for it, the devs just threw that option, and people on the internet speculating which option suits your play style. I mean it is a racing game, who cares for such customization? DiRT 3 Complete Edition also had this feature, but it was mostly useful car driving aspects. If I really wanted to waste 100 hours learning to customize car driving, I would buy a car and drive it in real life, even driving a car in real life is easier to drive it in FH4, FH4 is not a realistic racing game, it just pretends to be. After all, it is a racing game, you should press forward, and car should go vroom vroom, not swush swosh.

The good thing is that there is still offline part of the game, so you still can drive and race (for the most part).

I'll be honest, I did enjoy this game but for multiple reasons I can't recommend anyone buy it in it's current state, which isn't going to change since they've long since abandoned this for FH5.

First off, the bugs. Even on Xbox series X, you can reliably crash the game to your home screen by simply going into the festival menu, backing out and re-entering. Playing the game with a wheel is hit or miss, sometimes it works fine. Sometimes you'll be playing and all of your controls suddenly drop and remap to something else. Sometimes the game just freezes on you for no reason. Twice now my PC shut down on it's own without warning just going through cars in the menu, while apparently drawing nearly 200w from the GPU and pushing it at/above 70C. (4K/high preset, limited to 60fps on a 5700XT.) My fiance's nephew used to play this a lot via the microsoft store version, but his save file dropped after having hundreds of hours and now it's making him start over.. I'm also pretty sure this specific game destroyed the 980 Ti I gave him after also handing down a 1080p144hz monitor when my fiance gave me a birthday upgrade.  

Bugs aside the game just has some really annoying quirks. Festival hosts, after you're done with some events will just suddenly decide when and where you're going while you're in the middle of going through all the races for a particular event just to forcefully shoehorn in another type of event. Fast travelling will play unskippable DLC advertisements at random. For a game that's portrayed as an open world arcade style driving game, it sure does like to butt that freedom of exploration out of the way on a regular basis.

This game used to be fun but it's just not worth it anymore. Even if you have a decent experience, knowing that the prior Forza Horizon games aren't even available for sale anymore unless you get a disc copy, you're on a timer for how long you can even enjoy this game at all before online servers are completely shut down and you can no longer sign into the game to play it singleplayer. I'm pretty sure the online races are gone now, not that I really participated in them anyways but that's another reason to probably not bother buying it at this point.

Man, I hate Xbox games. Old Xbox games weren't this annoying. They started doing it somewhere since mid 2010s, implemented Xbox login requirement (it already was annoying in AoE3:DE), but to make you login every single time you open the game is just evil.

Also, cars slide too much, like you slightly press right/left, and your car loses control on the turn like it is Toyota Supra going full speed, but no, it is just a family car that goe to 100 in 6 seconds, so how does such slow car loses control on a simple turn? Realism? No. Gran Turismo is considered the most realistic game (there is even a documentary about it), even it didn't have such ridiculous controls. That is because you have 10-20 bar options where you slide them left or right to customize your cars "control" or "feel", if you will. But there is no simple guide for it, the devs just threw that option, and people on the internet speculating which option suits your play style. I mean it is a racing game, who cares for such customization? DiRT 3 Complete Edition also had this feature, but it was mostly useful car driving aspects. If I really wanted to waste 100 hours learning to customize car driving, I would buy a car and drive it in real life, even driving a car in real life is easier to drive it in FH4, FH4 is not a realistic racing game, it just pretends to be. After all, it is a racing game, you should press forward, and car should go vroom vroom, not swush swosh.

The good thing is that there is still offline part of the game, so you still can drive and race (for the most part).
